content:
Growing up, my kitchen was a battleground of smells. On one side, there was my dad’s side of the family—the German-American half. That meant mashed potatoes, pot roast, and maybe some sauerkraut if we were feeling adventurous. It was “normal” food. It smelled like butter and salt. Then there was my mom’s side. She moved here from Malaysia when she was in her twenties, and her cooking smelled like everything at once: pungent shrimp paste, sharp ginger, and spicy sambal that made me sneeze the second I walked through the door.

To be honest, for a long time, I hated it.

I remember this one time in middle school when my mom packed me laksa in a thermos for lunch. When I opened it in the cafeteria, this thick, coconut-curry scent drifted out. It wasn't bad, but it was *loud*. My friend Tyler made a face and asked, “What is that? It smells like old fish.” I felt my face get hot. I shoved the lid back on and told him it was just some weird soup my mom made. I didn't eat the rest of the day.

After that, I started asking for Uncrustables and chips. I wanted to be the kid with the brown paper bag that didn't draw any attention. I started feeling ashamed of how my mom would spend hours pounding spices in a mortar and pestle. I’d see her hands stained yellow from turmeric and just think about how much easier it would be if we just had spaghetti like everyone else. I was trying so hard to lean into my "American" side that I was basically pushing my mom’s culture out the door.

Everything changed during my sophomore year when my grandma (my Ma Ma) came to visit from Malaysia. She didn't speak much English, but she spoke through food. One afternoon, she decided to teach me how to make Hainanese chicken rice. I tried to make an excuse to go to my room, but she grabbed my wrist and handed me a head of garlic.

As we worked, she showed me how the rice isn't just rice—it’s toasted in ginger and chicken fat until it glows. She told me stories (with my mom translating) about how this was the ultimate comfort food back home. When we finally sat down to eat, I didn't just taste the salt or the spice. I tasted the effort. I realized that while I was busy being embarrassed, my mom and grandma were literally pouring their history into these bowls.

I started looking at my mom’s cooking differently after that. I realized that her "weird" ingredients weren't something to hide; they were her way of staying connected to a home she left thousands of miles away. Now, when I walk into the house and smell that sharp scent of shrimp paste, I don't cringe. I actually get hungry. 

I’m still half German-American, and I still love a good burger. But I’ve stopped trying to be "normal." Now, I’m the kid who brings leftovers to school and doesn't care if the cafeteria smells like curry. If someone asks what it is, I don’t say "weird soup." I tell them it’s my mom’s specialty, and honestly, they’re missing out.

I feel like everyone is always in a huge rush. My friends are always stressed about their SAT scores or trying to build some crazy resume for college, but honestly, I’m just not built like that. People call me "chill," which I guess is just a nice way of saying I don't really have a sense of urgency. But if I’m being real, my version of a perfect day isn't about doing something big or productive. It’s about the small stuff that actually makes life feel good.

My perfect day would start pretty late. I’m definitely not an early bird. I’d wake up when the sun is actually up and go straight to the kitchen to make a cup of tea. I’m not a coffee guy—it makes me too jittery, and I like staying at a level five out of ten energy-wise. I’d probably go with Earl Grey or maybe something herbal if I’m feeling extra relaxed. Then, I’d just sit on the couch with a book for a solid two hours. I’m currently into sci-fi, and there’s something so nice about being completely sucked into another world while the house is still quiet.

Eventually, I’d have to leave the house, but only for something fun. I’d meet up with my friends for lunch at this taco place near my neighborhood. We aren't the type of group that needs to go on some big adventure; we’re perfectly happy just sitting in a booth for way too long, eating chips and salsa and talking about nothing. That’s the best part about being chill—you don’t need a plan. You just hang out and see where the conversation goes.

After lunch, we’d probably head back to someone’s house to play video games. I’m not really into those super competitive shooters where everyone is screaming into their headsets. I much prefer co-op games like *Stardew Valley* or *Overcooked*. There’s something hilarious about failing a level together and just laughing it off instead of getting mad. It’s just about the vibes, not the high score.

By the time the sun starts going down, I’d be back home. The finale of my perfect day is definitely the "rot on the couch" phase. I’d turn on a show I’ve probably already seen three times—like *The Office* or some random documentary—and my cat, Mochi, would immediately come over. He’s basically the animal version of me. He just wants to sit there, be warm, and not be bothered. Having him purring next to me while I’m wrapped in a blanket is basically peak existence.

I know some people might think this sounds boring, but to me, it’s everything. Life is already loud and stressful enough at school. If I can spend twenty-four hours just being quiet, hanging with my favorite people, and petting my cat, I’d say that’s a pretty successful day. I don’t need to climb a mountain to feel like I did something important. Sometimes, just being relaxed is enough.

I feel like I spend half my life looking at a screen, and honestly, it’s kind of exhausting. Social media is one of those things where I can’t really imagine my life without it, but sometimes I really wish I could. It’s like this weird love-hate relationship that everyone my age just accepts as normal.

On one hand, it’s how I actually stay in the loop. If I wasn’t on Instagram or TikTok, I feel like I’d literally be a ghost. It’s how my friends and I send each other dumb memes at 11 p.m. to show we’re thinking of each other, and it’s how I see what my cousins in Florida are doing without having to have an awkward twenty-minute phone call. During the pandemic, it was basically a lifeline. It makes the world feel smaller and more connected, which is supposed to be a good thing.

But then there’s the downside, which feels like it’s getting worse the older I get. My attention span is basically nonexistent now. I’ll sit down to do my history homework, tell myself I’m just going to check one notification, and suddenly forty-five minutes have passed. I’ve watched thirty videos of people making pasta or organizing their closets, and I haven't even written the first sentence of my essay. It’s like my brain is rewired to only focus on things that are fifteen seconds long. I try to read a book for English class and I find myself reaching for my phone every two pages just out of habit. It’s actually kind of scary how much control the "scroll" has over me.

The worst part, though, is the "highlight reel" effect. I know, logically, that nobody’s life is perfect. I know people use filters and only post when they’re at a cool party or on vacation. But when I’m sitting in my room in my pajamas feeling bored, and I see someone from school posting these amazing, aesthetic photos at a beach or out with a huge group of friends, I still get that sting of jealousy. It makes me feel like I’m failing at being a teenager. You start comparing your "behind the scenes" to everyone else’s polished front page. It makes everything feel like a competition that I didn't even sign up for.

I’ve tried deleting the apps before, but I usually last about two days. I end up feeling left out of the jokes or I miss a plan someone made in a group chat. It’s like you’re forced to participate if you want a social life, but the price you pay is your focus and your self-esteem. I guess I’m just trying to find a balance, but it’s hard when the apps are literally designed to keep you hooked. For now, I’m just trying to be more aware of it—maybe I’ll put my phone in the other room while I finish this essay. Or at least I’ll try.

So, looking back at it now, my interview for Northwood Prep was probably the most mortifying thirty minutes of my entire life. At the time, I honestly thought my future was over. I had spent weeks practicing "professional" answers in the mirror, wearing a tie that was way too tight, and trying to sound like a forty-year-old businessman instead of a fourteen-year-old who still liked playing video games.

The disaster started about two minutes in. I was so nervous that my hands were shaking, and when the admissions officer, Mr. Henderson, offered me a glass of water, I managed to knock the entire thing over. It didn't just spill; it launched across his desk, soaking his stack of brochures and dripping onto his very expensive-looking rug. I froze. My face felt like it was literally on fire. Instead of saying something cool or collected, I blurts out, "Well, I guess I’m making a splash," and then immediately wanted to crawl into a hole and die.

Mr. Henderson didn't laugh. He just stared at the puddle.

For the next ten minutes, I was a total wreck. I kept forgetting the "perfect" answers I had memorized. When he asked me about my favorite book, I blanked so hard I couldn't even remember the title of *The Great Gatsby*, which I had literally finished the night before. I ended up rambling about a comic book I read in middle school. I felt like a complete fraud. I wasn't the "distinguished scholar" I was trying to be; I was just a clumsy kid who couldn't even hold a cup of water.

But then, something weird happened. Since I figured I had already failed, I stopped trying to be perfect. I took a deep breath and just said, "I’m really sorry. I’m incredibly nervous because I actually really want to go here, and I’m currently doing a terrible job of showing you why."

Mr. Henderson actually smiled for the first time. He told me to relax and asked why I was so stressed. I ended up talking to him—not like an interviewer, but like a person. I told him about how I struggle with being a perfectionist and how I was terrified of making a mistake. We talked about how being "genuine" is actually harder than being "perfect."

I walked out of that room sure I wouldn't get in, but a few weeks later, I got the acceptance letter. Mr. Henderson had actually written a little note on the bottom that said he appreciated my "honesty under pressure."

That whole embarrassing experience taught me that being a "perfect" candidate isn't really the point. If I had just sat there and recited memorized lines, he wouldn't have known who I actually was. Spilling that water was the best thing that could have happened because it forced me to show how I handle a mess—literally. It showed me that growth doesn't come from getting everything right the first time; it comes from being able to laugh at yourself, clean up the water, and keep talking anyway.

Last summer was honestly the worst time of my life. My parents finally got their divorce finalized after two years of constant fighting, and it felt like my entire world just kind of collapsed. I felt like I didn't even know who I was anymore because so much of my identity was tied up in being the "peacekeeper" at home. I was exhausted, sad, and just totally numb. So, when my mom suggested we take a trip to Bali just the two of us to "reset," I wasn't really sure it would help, but I knew I needed to get away from my house.

The second we landed in Denpasar, it was like a total sensory overload. The air was so humid it felt like a blanket, and it smelled like incense and tropical flowers. We stayed in this small place in Ubud that was surrounded by rice paddies. For the first few days, I honestly just slept. I think my body was finally realizing it didn't have to be on high alert for an argument anymore.

One morning, we went to the Tirta Empul temple for a purification ritual. I’m not really a religious person, but standing in the cold spring water with a bunch of strangers felt weirdly powerful. As the water hit my head, I kept thinking about all the stress of the last year—the yelling, the moving boxes, the awkward silence at dinner. I realized I had been carrying all that weight around like it was my job to fix it. Letting go of that feeling was the first step in finding myself again.

What really changed things for me, though, was just the pace of life there. In high school, everything is so fast and everyone is always trying to be someone they aren’t. In Bali, people seemed so present. I started spending my afternoons just walking around or sitting in cafes without my phone. I started drawing again, which is something I totally gave up when things got bad at home. I realized that the "authentic" me wasn't the sad kid in the middle of a divorce; I was someone who liked art, spicy food, and being quiet.

I also did a lot of thinking about my parents. I used to think the divorce meant our family was a failure, but being in such a beautiful, peaceful place helped me see it differently. It was just a change. Like the seasons or the tides. I started to feel like I could breathe again without feeling guilty about it.

By the time we had to leave, I didn't feel like a completely different person, but I felt like I had my "spark" back. Healing from trauma isn't like a movie where everything is fixed in one trip, but Bali gave me the space to remember who I was before everything broke. I learned that even when your world falls apart, you can still build something new and maybe even better. I’m back at school now, and things are still hard sometimes, but I try to keep a little bit of that Bali peace with me.

When I was younger, I used to think my lunchbox was like a flashing sign that said, “Not from here.” I’m half Chinese and half German-American, but the part that felt the loudest at school was my mom being a Malaysian immigrant. She speaks English with this careful, slightly musical accent, and she cooks like she’s still living in the humid streets of Kuala Lumpur, even though we’re in a bland suburban neighborhood where people think pepper is “spicy.”

In elementary school, my mom packed me food that actually had a smell. Not just a smell—like, a presence. There would be fried rice with bits of egg and green onion, or leftover curry that had soaked into the rice overnight. Sometimes it was sambal on the side, this bright red chili paste that looked like it could melt plastic. I would crack my lunch open and instantly feel my stomach drop. Kids would lean over and say stuff like, “What is that?” or “Ew, it stinks.” They weren’t even always trying to be mean. They just didn’t know, and I didn’t want to be the person who had to explain.

So I started asking my mom for “normal” lunches. I said it like it was a simple request, like asking for a different color shirt. “Can you just make me a sandwich? Like turkey?” She would pause for a second, and I could tell she didn’t totally get it, but she tried. She bought sliced bread and deli meat, and she packed it with chips like the other moms did. I acted relieved, but honestly it tasted like nothing. The sandwich would be kind of soggy by lunchtime, and I’d still feel weird, like I had traded something real for something that only looked right.

At home, though, I still ate my mom’s food. I’d stand in the kitchen while she cooked, watching her move fast without measuring, like her hands already knew. She would talk to me while stirring a pot, and sometimes she’d switch between English and Mandarin without even noticing. My dad—who’s German-American and likes things “simple”—would still go back for seconds. That always confused me. If he wasn’t embarrassed, why was I?

The turning point wasn’t one big moment. It was more like a bunch of small ones that added up. In middle school I started going to friends’ houses and realizing their dinners were kind of…sad. Like plain chicken breast and steamed broccoli every night. No hate, but it felt like food that was trying not to bother anyone. Around the same time, I started paying attention to how my mom lit up when she talked about her childhood. She’d describe night markets and hawker stalls and how her mom taught her to make certain dishes. I realized her cooking wasn’t just food. It was memory. It was survival. It was how she carried her whole life across an ocean.

One day in high school, we had this “heritage potluck” thing. I almost didn’t bring anything, but my mom insisted on making nasi lemak. The night before, our kitchen smelled like coconut milk and pandan and toasted peanuts. I remember thinking, This is going to be so embarrassing. But when I put it on the table at school, people actually lined up. A girl in my history class said, “Wait, this is amazing—what is it?” And for once, I didn’t shrink. I told her the name, and I told her my mom made it, and I felt proud saying it.

Now I still cringe sometimes when my mom is loudly bargaining at the Asian grocery store or when she packs my little brother something that smells “too strong.” But I catch myself defending it. I even crave it. When I’m stressed, the idea of her soup feels like being understood without talking. I think I was ashamed because I wanted to disappear into everyone else’s idea of “

People call me “chill,” and I guess that’s true. I’m not the type who needs to have every second planned or be doing something “productive” all the time. Honestly, my perfect day is kind of simple, but it’s the kind of simple that makes me feel like my brain finally unclenches. If I could design a day exactly how I want it, it would start slow and stay cozy all the way through.

I’d wake up without an alarm blaring at me like I’m in an emergency situation. The first thing I’d do is make a cup of tea. Not in a fancy way either, just the normal routine: kettle on, mug out, pick a tea bag based on vibes. There’s something calming about the whole process, like it tells my body, “You don’t have to sprint today.” I like sitting there while it steeps, watching the steam rise, and feeling my hands warm up around the mug. It’s such a small thing, but it sets the tone.

Then I’d grab a book and read for a while. I’m not always good at reading when school is busy, because my mind keeps trying to jump ahead to whatever I’m stressed about. But on a perfect day, I can actually sink into the story. I like when the house is quiet and I can hear the pages turning, and I don’t have to check my phone every five minutes. I’m not trying to speed-run the book, either. I just want to be in it for a bit, like a break from real life.

By late morning or early afternoon, I’d meet up with friends for lunch. Nothing too fancy—just a place where we can talk and not feel rushed. I love that part of the day because it’s like the social version of comfort. We’d probably talk about dumb stuff, like a random video we saw, or something that happened in class, or what game we’re all stuck on. There’s something really nice about laughing in public and not caring if we’re a little loud.

After lunch, the ideal plan is co-op video games. I’m not super competitive, so co-op is perfect because it feels like you’re on the same team instead of trying to destroy each other. I like when we’re all working together and it gets chaotic in a funny way. Like someone accidentally presses the wrong button and everything goes wrong, and instead of getting mad we just laugh and try again. It’s honestly one of my favorite ways to hang out, because we’re doing something together but there’s no pressure to be “deep” the whole time.

And then the night part of my perfect day is just watching TV next to my cat. My cat always acts like he doesn’t care about anyone, but the second I sit down, he suddenly needs to be there. He’ll curl up beside me and act like he owns the couch, and I’ll put on some comfort show I’ve already seen. I like that feeling of winding down when nothing is expected of me anymore.

That’s my perfect day: tea, pages, friends, games, and a cat-shaped blanket. It’s not dramatic or exciting, but it feels like me. And honestly, that’s enough.

I didn’t get social media because I thought it would change my life or anything. At first it was just a way to keep up with people. In middle school especially, it felt like if you weren’t on Instagram or Snapchat, you were basically invisible. Everyone would be laughing about something from a story, or planning stuff in a group chat, and if you weren’t there you’d find out later and feel kind of left out. So I downloaded the apps and told myself it would just be for “checking in” with friends.

And honestly, sometimes it really does connect me. I like seeing my cousins’ posts because they live in a different state and I don’t get to see them much. My grandma has Facebook and she comments on everything like “Love this!” with a million exclamation points. It’s kind of embarrassing but also sweet, because it means she’s paying attention. When one of my friends moved away last year, social media was how we stayed close. We’d send videos back and forth and keep each other updated on random stuff like a teacher being annoying or a new song we found. In those moments, social media feels like a bridge. It makes the distance smaller.

But then there’s the other side, which I try not to ignore because it’s the part that messes with me. I’ll open TikTok to watch one video and suddenly forty minutes are gone. It’s not even like I’m enjoying it the whole time. It’s more like my brain goes on autopilot and I’m just scrolling because the next thing might be interesting. Sometimes I’ll put my phone down and feel sort of gross and restless, like I ate too much candy. I notice my attention span getting worse too. I’ll start homework and immediately want to check my phone “for a second.” Or I’ll try to watch a movie with my family and I can’t stop thinking about what I’m missing online, which is dumb because it’s usually nothing important.

The jealousy part is what I hate admitting. I know people don’t post their worst moments. Nobody’s posting themselves crying in the bathroom or failing a test. People post the best angle, the best lighting, the highlight reel. I understand that logically. But emotionally, it still gets to me. I’ll see someone’s perfect vacation photos or a group of friends at a party and I’ll suddenly feel like I’m doing life wrong. Like everyone else is constantly having fun and looking amazing and I’m just…not. Even when I know it’s curated, it’s hard not to compare. Sometimes it’s not even about looks. It’s about seeing people hang out without you, or watching someone else get attention, and it makes you question your own place in your friend group.

What’s complicated is that I don’t want to quit completely. When I take breaks, I feel calmer, but I also feel disconnected. It’s like social media is both the party and the noise outside the door. Lately I’ve been trying to set little boundaries, like leaving my phone in another room while I do homework, or turning off notifications for certain apps. I’m not perfect at it, but I’m noticing that I feel more like myself when I’m not constantly watching everyone else.

I think social media isn’t totally good or totally bad, which is annoying because I wish it was simpler. It helps me stay close to people I care about, but it also steals my focus and makes me compare my behind-the-scenes to someone else’s best moments. I’m still figuring out how to use it without letting it use me.

The first time I heard the words “prep school entrance interview,” I pictured a calm, impressive version of myself walking into a fancy office, shaking hands like I’d been doing it for years, and saying something smart about leadership and community service. In my head, I was basically a scholarship kid in a movie. In real life, I was a sweaty fourteen-year-old wearing a blazer that felt like a costume, sitting in the car outside the school and trying to remember if I was supposed to make eye contact for exactly three seconds or if that was a myth from the internet.

The campus was quiet in that way rich schools are quiet, like even the trees have good manners. My mom fixed my collar in the parking lot like I was five. I walked in and the lady at the front desk smiled and told me to take a seat. Everything smelled like lemon cleaner and old books. I tried to sit in a confident way, but the chair squeaked loudly and somehow it made me feel like I already failed.

Then the admissions guy came out and said my name. I stood up too fast, my folder slid out of my hands, and my papers went everywhere like confetti. Instead of just laughing and picking them up like a normal person, I panicked and blurted, “This is not how I usually am.” Which, honestly, was a lie. I’m exactly like that sometimes.

He helped me gather everything and led me into his office. There were framed photos on the walls and a little bowl of candy on his desk. He asked me basic questions like why I wanted to go there, what I liked to do, and what my favorite class was. All normal stuff. Except my brain decided to abandon me. I answered one question by saying, “I enjoy… reading and also… teamwork.” Like those were two hobbies you do on weekends.

At one point he asked what book I was currently reading, and I tried to sound impressive, but my mind went blank. The only title I could think of was *Diary of a Wimpy Kid* because my little brother had left it on the couch. So I said that. Then, for some reason, I tried to recover by adding, “But like, in an ironic way.” That made it worse. He raised his eyebrows a little, and I felt my face get hot. I started talking faster, and I knocked over the water bottle they’d given me. It rolled off the desk and water spilled on the carpet. I apologized about fifty times. He handed me paper towels like this happened every day, which somehow made me feel even more embarrassed.

When the interview ended, I walked out feeling like I’d just watched myself in third person doing every wrong thing possible. In the car, I told my mom, “I ruined it.” I couldn’t stop replaying it in my head. I was sure the admissions guy was writing notes like “clumsy,” “awkward,” and “possibly raised by wolves.”

But a weird thing happened after I got home. Once I got over wanting to crawl into my bed forever, I realized the interview was the first time I couldn’t hide behind being “the smart kid” or “the responsible one.” I was just me, messy and nervous and trying. And honestly, that’s real. I wrote a thank-you email where I admitted I was nervous and thanked him for being kind about it. I didn’t make excuses. I just owned it.

Whether I got in or not, that interview taught me something important: being impressive isn’t the same as being genuine. I learned that I can mess up in a big, public way and still keep going. I can be embarrassed and survive it. And if a school wants students who are perfect all the time, then maybe it wasn’t the right place anyway. But if it wants people who can learn, adjust, and laugh at themselves later, then I guess that interview

The year my parents divorced, everything in my life started to feel like it was made out of thin glass. Nothing was technically “broken” at school or with my friends, but I felt like I could shatter at any second. At home, the air felt heavier. Even normal stuff—like making dinner or doing laundry—had this weird sadness stuck to it. I didn’t know what to do with all the anger and confusion, so I did what I’m good at: I tried to act fine. I kept my grades up, answered “I’m good” when people asked, and scrolled on my phone late at night until I couldn’t think anymore.

When my mom suggested a trip to Bali that summer, I didn’t get it at first. Going somewhere pretty didn’t seem like it could fix anything. It almost felt wrong, like we didn’t deserve a vacation when our family had just fallen apart. But she said she needed to breathe, and honestly, I did too. So we went.

The first thing I noticed in Bali was how loud the world was in a different way. Not loud like arguing. Loud like scooters buzzing, birds yelling in the morning, and the ocean making this steady sound that didn’t change depending on anyone’s mood. At home, it always felt like I was listening for the next problem. In Bali, I started listening to things that weren’t about my parents at all. That alone felt like a break.

One day we took a walk through rice terraces early in the morning. The sun made everything look unreal, like someone turned the brightness up. I remember thinking, “The world is still here.” That sounds obvious, but it wasn’t to me. After the divorce, it felt like my world had ended, so seeing people just living—farmers working, kids laughing, tourists sweating and complaining—was a reminder that life doesn’t stop. It keeps moving, even if you don’t feel ready.

I also did something I didn’t expect: I cried in public. We were at a temple, and there were offerings everywhere, these small baskets with flowers and incense. It was quiet, and the smell was kind of sweet and smoky. I don’t know why, but I suddenly felt all the feelings I’d been holding in. Not just sadness, but embarrassment, and disappointment, and this deep tiredness from pretending. I cried without trying to hide it, and no one acted like it was a huge deal. My mom didn’t tell me to stop. She just stood next to me. That moment didn’t erase the trauma, but it made it feel less like a secret shame and more like something I could actually survive.

Over the week, I started noticing small parts of myself coming back. I laughed more. I took photos not to post, but because I genuinely wanted to remember. I wore a swimsuit without obsessing over how I looked. I tried new foods and didn’t panic about being “weird” or doing it wrong. It was like I remembered I had a personality outside of being someone’s kid in the middle of a messy breakup.

When we flew home, our problems weren’t magically solved. The divorce was still real, and it still hurt. But Bali gave me space to feel things without drowning in them. It showed me that healing isn’t one big moment where everything becomes okay. It’s more like waking up and choosing, little by little, to live as yourself again—even if your family doesn’t look the way you thought it would.
